awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Materials and Methods for Scalable Manufacturing of Flexible Resonant Sensors and their Wireless Readers.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercialization potential of this PFI project is to enable commercialization of a platform sensor technology, flexible resonant sensors, that has many potential applications in consumer, agriculture, and health markets.  In the consumer market, the sensor system can be applied to wearable technologies to monitor stretch and strain such as in performance athletic wear.  In agriculture, the sensor system can be applied to soil and water quality monitoring.  In health, the sensor system can be applied to monitoring of biotherapeutics in manufacturing and health status of closed wounds. Advantages of this sensor platform are its passive unit architecture (no on-board power), potential low cost, and ability to measure in closed systems. This PFI will enable the founding of one or more startups in these market spaces, which will in turn lead to increased employment opportunities and economic development.  Moreover, this project will train two graduate students and 10 undergraduates with technical skills in materials, electronics, and characterizations tools in an interdisciplinary environment.  They will also receive valuable innovation skills in product design, reliability, robustness, and commercialization due to the project scope and inclusion of active industrial partners. These students with special attention to those underrepresented in STEM fields.


The proposed project addresses attributes needed to commercialize resonant sensors that are common to all market sectors, namely 1) the methods and materials to enable scalable fabrication of the sensors, 2) the materials and methods to encapsulate (package) the sensors, and 3) custom reader hardware and analysis software to lower the cost and improve read range of the resonant sensor.  For the first, screen-printable inks that are optimized for inductive resonance will be developed and large-batch (>1000 unit) methods of printing and roll to roll fabrication will be demonstrated. For the second, elastomeric encapsulants and flexible, polymeric substrates will be evaluated for their performance with resonant sensors.  In the third, a low-cost (<$100) custom reader will be developed to supplant the more expensive portable vector network analyzers currently in use and to improve sensor read range.  In each of these specific areas, performance will be assessed in actual end-use scenarios through existing research programs we have on resonant sensors for consumer, agriculture, and health applications.  The anticipated technical results include optimal material formulations for flexible resonant sensor fabrication and packaging, hardware specifications for low-cost readers, and methods to produce the sensors and readers at large scale, thus enabling commercialization entry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Over the duration of this PFI-RP project PI-Reuel worked closely with the industrial Co-PIs, Drs. Luke Bu and Sang-Hwan Kim to advance applications of resonant sensors in wearable health technologies, agricultural sensors, biomanufacturing sensors, viral diagnostics, and material deformation sensors.  To date this has resulted in seven published papers, with three more in preparation and three patents (one granted two pending). The PFI industrial partners worked closely to identify best materials and guide development with a focus to future commercialization. The project support has enabled five graduate students to pursue their PhD studies, with a special focus in entrepreneurial skill development. Two students directly participated in I-Corps training. The work has also had success in technology transfer with two spinout startups pursuing aspects of the technology platform: 1) Skroot Laboratory Inc. pursuing contact-free biomanufacturing sensors and 2) Frugi Biotechnology Inc. pursuing scalable methods of cell free synthesis for diagnostics and drug discovery (an outcome of PFI supplemental funding to study use of resonators in diagnostics).  Both startups have been successful in obtaining NSF SBIR support and have benefited from PFI-trained students as co-founders and employees.

In pursuit of application feasibility testing, the team has also overcome one of the major barriers of resonant sensors – that is the effect of positional noise on sensor output. This effect is mitigated by including a secondary coupling coil (inductively coupled extender, ICE, element). This innovation will help realize resonant sensors in biomedical applications (such as smart bandages) that were not possible before.

Over the duration of this project Co-PI Neihart’s group collaborated with the rest of the PFI team on two critical tasks to commercial viability of this sensor platform: 1) modeling and characterization of the sensor coil for improved in silico design iteration, and 2) development of a custom sensor readout circuit for a lower cost, and longer-read range sensor reader.

During the modeling of the reader and sensor coil, they first extracted a lumped-element circuit model from a combination of theoretical equations based on the physical properties of the system and 2-port S-parameter measurements with the sensor coil exposed to both air and de-ionized water. The lumped-element model was then simulated assuming that the sensor coil was exposed to a 3 mMol/L concentration of potassium chloride and the results were compared against measurements using the same solution. The results of this modeling effort aided in a deeper understanding of the operation of the reader/sensor coil and resulted in a refined design.

The second task was the development of a custom readout circuit used for interrogating the sensor coil across multiple frequencies. The final design used a mixer as a coherent demodulator and a direct digital synthesizer as the excitation source to convert the changing electrical properties of the sensor coil into a DC voltage. The reader was fabricated on a printed circuit board and used entirely off-the-shelf components. The final design can interrogate the sensor coil over a frequency range of DC up to 100 MHz in steps of less than 1 Hz and is powered from a computer USB port. The performance of this system was verified by monitoring a sample of de-ionized water as it cooled from approximately 100 to 20 degrees C.

In summary, the PFI-RP grant was successful in bringing academic and industrial partners together to further application-oriented research of resonant sensors. This resulted in technology transfer to successful startups and enhanced career placement for graduate students involved.

 


Last Modified: 06/25/2022
Modified by: Nigel F Reuel
